New Records: The Dodgers became the second team in MLB history to throw a nine-inning postseason shutout using at least eight pitchers
Key Match Events: Mookie Betts hit a solo home run in the top of the first inning
Shohei Ohtani hit a 432-foot two-run homer in the bottom of the second inning
Will Smith hit a 432-foot two-run homer
Gavin Lux hit a three-run homer in the top of the fifth inning
Ryan Brasier, Anthony Banda, Michael Kopech, Alex Vesia, Evan Phillips, Daniel Hudson, Blake Treinen, and Landon Knack combined to pitch a shutout
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers decided to use a bullpen game due to a depleted starting rotation
Freddie Freeman was initially listed as the starting first baseman but was scratched less than two hours before the game
Miguel Rojas, the regular shortstop, was also unavailable due to a groin injury
Post-Match Reflections: Dodgers manager Dave Roberts praised the team's resilience and determination
The victory was seen as pivotal for the Dodgers' playoff push
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Padres were shut out for the first time since July 19
The game marked the first time the Padres had been shut out in the postseason since July 19, 2024
The Dodgers will have a home advantage in Game 5
Others: The game was a must-win for the Dodgers to avoid elimination
The series will return to Dodger Stadium for Game 5
